Blog.post: Whatever happened to the Spar Dancers?

Nearly there so. Just start addin' d'oul pictures now. Big respect to Ail and her simple but effective drawing of how directories work. She be illin, as we say in these here parts. Shhh, I can hear the whelks.

If anyone comes across this page by chance (not very likely) please ignore our/my/its appearance for the moment. the whole html thing is a learning curve for me and I've got a 6 week old daughter to look after as well (hello Molly if you are reading this in the future!! You smiled at me today) so - come back later or better yet, give me a mail with your thoughts on what I could do with this space weblog@daraghotoole.com cheers D.
Testing blogger for my site. Wonder if this will all work? Who knows. Kind of lame for a first entry.

MOLLYNEWS. Latest development. Molly is starting to figure out she can do stuff with her hands, apart from waving them about. She is playing with her fingers and trying to hold her bottles. Last night she was determined to grab an empty bag of crisps I was holding and and taste it. Is this child a genius or what?
HMM.. Jack L... Sonny Knowles for the 0's? I'll have to tot up the appearances on Live at 3 to see if this ones a runner.

MOLLYNEWS If anyone wants to come - Molly is going to be Christened by Lallys Uncle Willy in St. Michaels Church in Dun Laoghaire next Saturday. It's on at 12.30 and we will be going across the road to the Royal Marine Hotel after for wine and nibbly things. Come along and bring a friend.

Urrgghh Yuck - hangover today. Went to Gravity last night. great venue - had way too much Guinness. Home to very sad and overheated Molly. We ended up blowing on her in the middle of the night to cool her down. Worked like a charm. She is in much better humour today - and is having a sleep with Lally right now. I'm in work all day today. Me and Paula hacking away at the coalface. I may never drink a certain well known soft drink again in my life, ever. Make it go away.

DON'T BE SHY Hey kids (anyone who is passing by - if I know you or not) See that email button to the left. Why not use it? Go on - brighten up those bits of the day when I'm not hanging with the Mollster.

MOLLYNEWS Molly had a fun weekend. On Saturday we spent the morning singing Winnie the Pooh songs and gurgling. The Eyeore song is definitely her favorite. If anyone wants a transcript of the Lyrics email Molly. Sunday we visited the Garden Show in the RDS (Not very good BTW). She also had lunch in Yamamori with her Granny O'T.

DIE DIE DIE Dear F**KER in the Red Micra - 9.15 AM Friday 13, Constitution Hill. Next time you clip me I will take off your wing mirror.... Just pray you don't meet me on a flat where I can catch you, you gimpy fool. And by the way, the Micra is a crappy excuse for a car. Arrrggghhhh Rant over.

CALL FOR ENTRIES Anyone want to to do black and white drawings to keep Molly amused? I'm looking for simple shapes/doodles with no greys etc to stick over her cot. She seems to get a buzz from looking at shapes - she is fascinated by Nigels drawing in our front room, and by the set of black keys Orna gave me - which hangs over where I change her nappy. Abstract shapes probably - nothing scary (big faces etc) maybe letterforms. I'll post the best ones here. later - DOT

THE SOUND OF SILENCE As some of you may have noticed, NTL Cable was down last night in Dublin 8. This meant no Voyager for me. Hope I didn't miss the last episode... Speaking of which, did the last X Files blow big time or not? No TV. Molly musta wondered where all the attention was coming from. (No, I'm not a bad father, before you start mailing)
SON OF STRANGE AND BIZARRE Nathan just emailed me this - http://www.dara.ie Who knew a silent 'gh' could be so important??

HELLO Hi Ruth, you are the only person who has owned up to actually reading this weblog. Boring, isn't it. STRANGE AND BIZARRE Gerry Adams in the paper this weekend, talking about how he hugs trees. I hope those trees are native Irish Oaks Gerry, and not some Plantation blow-ins..

RESOLUTION OF THE WEEK Might not work, but this week i'm going to try and not use any stock imagery... phew, there i've said it. Small steps, day by day, building a better tomorrow. (Que John Williams soundtrack) Fade to Black
ALBUM OF THE MOMENT Ani Difranco and Utah Phillips - Fellow Workers. Brilliant, Brilliant, Brilliant. You'll never complain about the 8 hour day again. http://www.utahphillips.org/

BABYNEWS Molly was awake this AM at 4.30. How can a seven week old be so much more alert than me? And she wanted to play. Is this a sign of things to come. Should I start sleeping in the middle of the day (Current and prospecive employers ignore that last bit)...
SITENEWS Bold heads, Arial, it's enough to make your head spin. In fact, I feel dizzy. Deadly.

BABYNEWS Molly did he biggest PUKE I've ever seen this morning!! I was out the door and halfway to the hospital before Mary Bowen told me it was perfectly normal. Luckily she got me before I made a fool of myself in the A&E. OTHERSTUFF Aiden won a GBDA IDEA award last week. Well done Aido. Full news on www.bfk.ie/grey/unshocked/newsindex.htm All glory and honour to you, etc... _____ I got another new bike last night. The chap in the bike shop was very apologetic about the heap of crap they sold me first. So I now have a nice shiny red and black mountain bike with a decent set of gears and a saddle that won't make Molly an only child. Daragh O'Toole - Urban Road Warrior

BABYNEWS Mikes wife had a baby girl about an hour ago according to Enda. Welcome to the world kiddo SITENEWS Hey, they rollovers work. I think. Loads of testing to be done. Aileen made me redo the table on the front page as it was full of nightmarish html gibberish. Dreamweaver is a tool of Satan, apparently. I should really figure out all these Blogger tags so I can do different weights etc. And I hate default Times. It is GICK. Soon this page will all be Arial, and who'll be sorry then... Earlier . . . The rollovers on the homepage don't work in Netscape. I hate dreamweaver - bah humbug

SITENEWS I'm updating the site to provide an intro page that links to the main sections - Molly stuff and this log. In the future I'm going to have a CV/portfolio section, a guestbook and any other bells and whistles I can think of. But I wouldn't hold your breath.. OTHERSTUFF Nathan is celebrating his birthday this weekend. Happy 12th birthday Warnapoko. _____ As it's the 4th of july I would like to nominate (the small, but perfectly formed) Mr. Martin Sheen for President of the world. _____ The chain on my bike jammed halfway up the hill to Thomas Street last night - nearly killing me in traffic. I had to walk home, sweaty and covered in grease. The chaps in the Liffey Valley Motor store where I bought it are going to get an earful this evening.

MOLLYNEWS Molly had her 6 week checkup (even though she is 7 weeks old?) today which went swimmingly. She is doing really well on all fronts. G'wan the Mollser. OTHER STUFF Today is also Gavins birthday. Happy birthday Gav - the cake was manky, wasn't it. The new bike is shite. I had to adjust the saddle twice and now the gears keep slipping. That'll teach me not to be cheap in the future. Back to the shop tomorrow for a replacement.

I bought a new bike yesterday. My last one was stolen from outside the office about a week ago. My fault - I left it with no lock overnight. That makes eleven bikes in 8 years or so. Is this a record? The worst part is the way the Guards seem to regard bike theft as a non crime. The good news is that we have the little feckers who nicked on security camera. I feel a few slaps coming on... _______________________ MOLLYNEWS We had a good weekend of gurgles and smiles. Molly was a big hit at her Aunty Mia's BBQ. She also moved into her new cot on Friday night. It's huge - but I'm sure she will fill it soon. New Molly pics coming to this site soon.

Getting bored of this layout so I've decided to change the whole site. I've created a new template for the Molly section using layers which I think I might adapt for the rest. Last time I used layers was for the first version of Lorraines site and it was a disaster - nothing worked properly and half the people visiting had steam driven browsers... We got tickets for Slane today... I'm not a huge U2 fan (and I think Ash are gimps) but seems like it will be a good day. I'm going to drive up and not drink. (You can stop laughing now). Sonia has given me some directions to a secret parking spot about half a mile from the concert >> Fingers crossed.
Where in the world.. Set up a blog for Steve Mangan so everyone can follow his exploits in South America and the rest of the world - click here to have a look >>> urlLink Keep It Country

Green around the gills Spent Saturday night drinking in the Harbour with Orna, Lew, Lally, Paul and some very large Cubans. (Cigars I mean). Sick as a dog on Sunday morning - unlike Orna and Lew who were up at 8 to drive to Donegal to go surfing. Bleedin health freaks - it's not natural.
Have a look Thanks to urlLink erin for the nice words.Have a look at her site, it's lovely

HOLLIERS. We are off to Bray for Saturday and Sunday. Molly is staying with her grandparents Saturday night while Lally and I go to the pub!! For drinks. In glasses. I've come over all dizzy. So - if anyone is around we'll be in the Harbour Bar (where else) from around 8ish.

LAZYBOY. Sorry to any of my confirmed readers (Dave and Ruth so far) for not updating this log more often. Stuff keeps getting in the way. Work etc.. I could keep it full with bits and pieces filched from other sites but that would be cheating, wouldn't it?
MOLLYNEWS. Today was Mollys official 3 month check up. Which she passed with flying colours. Go on the Moll!!

MOLLYNEWS. Molly had a great day at her Christening. Lorainne made her a lovely dress and she was the Belle of the ball. Thanks to everyone who came - especially for all the prezzies. We may have to move to a bigger house. There are about a zillion pictures and some video of the event - I'm hoping to put some of it up on this site soon. I'll mail everyone when I do.

TURNING and turning in the widening gyre The falcon cannot hear the falconer; Things fall apart; the centre cannot hold; Mere anarchy is loosed upon the world, The blood-dimmed tide is loosed, and everywhere The ceremony of innocence is drowned; The best lack all conviction, while the worst Are full of passionate intensity. Surely some revelation is at hand; Surely the Second Coming is at hand. The Second Coming! Hardly are those words out When a vast image out of 'Spiritus Mundi' Troubles my sight: somewhere in sands of the desert A shape with lion body and the head of a man, A gaze blank and pitiless as the sun, Is moving its slow thighs, while all about it Reel shadows of the indignant desert birds. The darkness drops again; but now I know That twenty centuries of stony sleep Were vexed to nightmare by a rocking cradle, And what rough beast, its hour come round at last, Slouches towards Bethlehem to be born? .
Stevo in Peru. Your life is bland and uninteresting compared to our Steve. Check it out - new entry >>> urlLink Keep It Country

Finally made it to Slane on Saturday. We arrived just before Moby came onstage and I have to say he was excellent - much better than expected. And then it was time for the 'biggest, bestest' band in the world. Wow - I couldn't wait. Two songs into the set I realised - hey, the sound is crap, they aren't messing around with the echo for a laugh. We were standing about near the top of the hill - right in the middle. All we could hear was a huge echo through most of the gig. Everytime Bono would say something we'd hear it twice. It was like hearing the whole gig from the bottom of a swimming pool. Excuse my language but it was a F**KING MESS. How can the production team of the biggest band in the world screw up like this. Did anyone bother with a soundcheck!!!! Ash must have done, Moby certainly did. What is the story? I know people further down the hill had a great time and I'm sure a lot of people didn't even notice but there must have been a couple of thousand people standing around me looking at each other in disbelief. And then to make it worse - just at the end the sound was mysteriously fixed - so we heard "Walk On' perfectly. One song ???? Not good enough.
A working Pez link This should work now urlLink PEZ Yum yum - all the Billy Roll you can eat...

How Sad Am I... In no particular order - my favourite SF (and some fantasy) books at the moment Iain M. Banks - Player of Games, Against a Dark Background , Excession, Use of Weapons, Feersum Endjinn Frank Herbert - Dune Ursula K. Leguin - The Left Hand of Darkness, The Dispossessed , Earthsea Books Walter M. Miller Jr. - A Canticle for Leibowitz George R. Stewart - Earth Abides Vernor Vinge - A Fire Upon the Deep Greg Bear - Eon Alfred Bester - The Demolished Man, Tiger Tiger C.J. Cherryh - Forty Thousand in Gehenna, Cyteen Richard Cowper - Profundis Joe Haldeman - The Forever War Daniel Keyes - Flowers for Algernon John Varley - Persistence of Vision Ray Bradbury - Something Wicked this Way Comes C.S. Lewis - The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe Philip K. Dick - Ubik, The Three Stigmata of Palmer Eldritch, Valis, A Scanner Darkly, Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep? Neal Stephenson - The Diamond Age Gene Wolfe - The Fifth Head of Cerberus Robert Silverberg - Lord Valentine 's Castle Larry Niven & Jerry Pournelle - Footfall, Lucifer's Hammer, The Mote In God's Eye I really should get out more.

Artificial Intelligence AI - bag of shite... great value for money though... 3 movies in one.. why is it than when Hollywood tries to do serious SF it all ends horribly... super duper evolved robots don't have to look like cocktail sticks.. That kid only has one expression... Jude Law will do ANYTHING for money (although Gattaca was v.good)..my final opinion - if you want interesting SF that will make you think READ A BOOK.. A good start would be the short story 'Super Toys Last All Summer' by Brian Aldiss - which this piece of poo is (v. broadly) based on. Much sadder and much shorter... from there move onto anything Aldiss wrote - Helliconia Spring, Summer and Winter are brilliant if you have a couple of weeks spare... If you are really interested in reading SF have a lurk urlLink here - you might pick up some ideas on where to start. PS avoid anything with an elf on the cover that comes in seven parts...

Time Flies. Molly is five months old today - Where did the time go?? And Hannah O'Connor is two on Wednesday - happy birthday Hanser. In Other News.. I'm back at college since last Tuesday - working on a subject for my MA Thesis at the moment. Something about Interactive Digital TV probably. Any links, resources etc.. send them to me. Urban Myths and jumping to conclusions... This is from www.mediawhore.co.nz Important! I am not usually in scare-mongering and internet-based rumour spreading, however this came to me earlier to day and it is something I felt I ought to share. I am sure that like minded people will understand/appreciate this warning. Yesterday my Auntie's friend's daughter was on the on the train travelling from Johannesburg to Cape Town. A man of Arabic-appearance got off the train and she noticed that he had left his bag behind. She grabbed the bag and ran after him, caught up with him at the top of the stairs and handed him back his bag. He was extremely grateful and reached into his bag which appeared to contain large bundles of bank notes. He offered her a reward, but she refused. So he looked round, made sure nobody was looking and whispered to her: "I can never repay your kindness, but I will try to with a word of advice for you." "Stay away from The Hard Rock Cafe". She was terrified. "Is there going to be an attack?" she whispered. "No" he whispered back "I went there yesterday evening - the food was shit and the waitress was fucking rude."
Had enough of the Internet?? urlLink Turn it off

Happy birthday to my little sister Orna, who is 28th today. Also big up to Joe Tierney who is 40 but doesn't look a day over 39.. Christ - I feel like Larry Gogan with all these dedications. speaking of which here are some actual answers from contestants who have appeared on the Just a Minute Quiz (thanks to James for these). Lets hope Larry gets well soon - what would life be like without gems like these. Name something a blind person might use -A sword Name a song with moon in the title - Blue suede moon Name a bird with a long neck -Naomi Campbell Name an occupation where you need a torch - A burglar Name a famous brother & sister - Bonnie & Clyde Name a dangerous race - The Arabs Name an item of clothing worn by the 3 musketeers - A horse Name something that floats in the bath - Water Name something you wear on the beach - A deckchair Name something Red - My cardigan Name a famous cowboy -Buck Rogers Name a famous royal - Mail A number you have to memorise - 7 Something you do before going to bed - Sleep Something you put on walls - Roofs Something in the garden that's green - Shed Something that flies that doesn't have an engine - A bicycle with wings Something you might be allergic to - Skiing Name a famous bridge - The bridge over troubled waters Something a cat does - Goes to the toilet Something you do in the bathroom - Decorate Name an animal you might see at the zoo - A dog Something associated with the police - Pigs A sign of the zodiac - April Something slippery - A conman A kind of ache - Fillet 'O' Fish A food that can be brown or white - Potato A jacket potato topping -Jam A famous Scotsman - Jock Another famous Scotsman - Vinnie Jones Something with a hole in it -Window A non living object with legs - Plant A domestic animal - Leopard A part of the body beginning with 'N' - Knee A way of cooking fish - Cod Something you open other than a door- Your Bowels

I've been lurking for a while on soc.history.what-if - its a brilliant newsgroup, full of gems like the following (well worth a look) thread on 'Alternate' books "Primary Colors" -- Fred Rogers' gentle guide to children's art activities, preschool through grade 3. "Kramer vs. Kramer" -- The indefatigable and fuzzy-haired science officer of the starship _Seinfeld_ is split into good and evil twins by a transporter malfunction. After much complication and conflict, he's restored to whatever state may be regarded as normal for him by _Seinfeld_'s chef, the redoubtable Soup Nazi, who dices up both twins and reconstitutes them by means of a rewired food replicator. A new title in the _Star_Drek_ series. "To Kill a Mockingbird" -- The offical NRA guide to precision shooting of small, hard-to-hit and utterly inoffensive avian targets. Foreword by Charlton Heston. "Guadalcanal Diary" -- Paul Theroux details the manifold wonders of this Pacific paradise, one of the key hospitality developments of the Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere. "Crusade in Europe" -- William Shakespeare's verse-form history of Henry V's triumphal eviction of Islamic forces from the continent. 1. "Private Parts": Renowned sex therapist Howard Stern discusses human sexuality and reproduction in a hard-hitting no nonsense fashion. 2. "The Hunt For Red October": The story about a time traveler from a Soviet-dominated future seeking to undo the Russian Revolution by any means necessary, and succeeding in creating a timeline where the USSR collapses in 1991 leading to European continental unification by 1999. Written by Comrade Toma Clancy, subsequently debriefed by Soviet police upon its publication. Clancy subsequently gets ten years in Alaska for sedition. 3. "War and Peace": by Dostoievsky (sp), a brilliant Russian tactician, focusing on all aspects of warfare, from traditional military conflict to economic warfare and political subversion. Considered the modern version of Sun Tzu. 4. "My Struggle": By the world-famous Austrian mountaineer and Jewish convert Adolf Schicklegruber, combining mountain-climbing imagery with spiritual metaphors, the most well-known being the climbing of Mt. Sinai to meet God. 5. "The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy": By Douglas Adams, it goes into detail the various sundry worlds of the Terran Confederation from the perspective of a stowaway on all sorts of spacecraft. It shares the Pulitzer Prize for Literature in 2098 with the autobiography "Star Trek" by space travel pioneer Gene Roddenberry. 6. "The Art of Talk" by Art Bell, it sparks a revolution in the field of speech pathology and therapy. 7. "The Firm": tawdry Triple-X pulp fiction by John Grisham, also known for his sex-novel about underwear, "The Pelican Brief". 8. "The Klingon Dictionary": by noted linguist Mark Okrand, who lived among the warlike aliens for several years learning their language. This work was instrumental in preventing the Enterprise Incident from leading to man's first ever interstellar war. 9. "The Hot Zone": Focuses on the tragedies of The Saharan Republic, the first nation in the world to employ the use of a supervirus in warfare. 10. "It Takes a Village": By noted Education Secretary Hillary Rodham, which in her book advocates nationalization of the (then private) education industry. A massive scandal about an affair between her and Bill Clinton leads to her being sacked (no pun intended) and a civil lawsuit by First Lady Gennifer Clinton urlLink check it out here

Sick all day yesterday - the cold that's doing the rounds laid me low for most of the day. Molly spent the day with her Granny so hoepfully she won't come down with it (fingers crossed). In between feeling sorry for myself I managed to finish the first book of the "His Dark Materials' trilogy by Phillip Pullman. This is being marketed as 'similar' to the Harry Potter books but IMHO is much more interesting. Very dark and kind of steampunky (without the punk).. The first book is called Northern lights (also called The Golden Compass in some editions) if you are interested. Good stuff. urlLink article on Phillip Pullman here
Came across this link a while ago - good place to go if you are sick of listening to the same CDs all day and (like me) are too skint to buy any new ones... urlLink Epitonic

The Harry Potter film open last week to disappointing crowds. Although the book series is higher successful in both the UK and the US (Where HP and the Cup of Hot Stuff sold over a million copies in a week), the adaptation is seen by many fans as having taken too many liberties with the text. Due to an unfortunate contract, the author, Rowling (Pictured here soon after her purchase of the Canary Islands) had very little say in the manner in which the text was adapted for film. Certainly the move of Hogwarts from the UK to New England went over poorly with test audiences and even though Dick Van Dyke was hired to teach Culkin to use a Cockney accent after Speilberg bowed to protests and restored Harry's original nationality, many felt the accent to be less authentic than was hoped. From urlLink SHWI

Creative Ireland is back... hooray.... Looking forward to Saturday.. me and Lally have our tickets for the worlds first (and probably last) screening of 'Fully Charged'... ta for the tickets Joe... here's a link from the recently older (and engaged(er)) Mr. Kenny urlLink not sure where I fit in this somewhere in the middle - my Klingon is a bit rusty...

I you are in a bookshop in the near future have a look at 'The art of looking sideways' by Alan Fletcher of Pentagram fame. The big book of inspiration is the best way I can describe it. ISBN 0-7148-3449-1

Where is Creative Ireland?? It's gone all quiet.. wonder what's up?? I'm going to have to start lurking elsewhere.... I love January - all the crap TV starts again on SKY, new trek series, new buffy etc... there goes evening conversation and quality time with the Mollser... Have to get some new CDs very very soon... daytime radio is doing my head in and we can only only take Ail's Amilie (spell?) soundtrack in very small doses...

Happy New Year and Happy New Euro to all my devoted readers. Quiet Xmas - Molly got loads of highly educational prezzies from Santa and all her family and friends (thanks all round). I now have scientific proof that babies are more interested in cardboard boxes and bits of string than expensive toys.. Molly also got her first two teeth over the holidays.. she's not sure what to make of them yet.. lots of dribbling and fingers in her mouth. Thank god for T-Gel and Tracy Chapman (who puts her too sleep in 3 minutes flat - does the same to me actually). Congrats to Aiden and Valerie who just got engaged - should we start planning the stag now Aido?? BTW - Does anyone know how Tom Dunne got the part in LOTR??

Long time no see...Things have been busy recently so no time to post to d'oul blog.. It was my Birthday on Thursday. Thanks for all the birthday greetings. I got a brand new phone from Lally and a radio shaped like a Seahorse from Molly, so I can listen to David Hanley in the Shower. Thanks Kiddo. I'm in college today, working on the iTV project with Sabina. Later on meself and Lally are heading off to Kildare for the night. Few beers and a couple of packets of Tayto - let the party begin.

That time of the year again when every resident of Inchicore except me decides to reenact the Intifada. Great for getting rid of an rubbish you may have lying around though. Burn baby burn... The small girl will be dressing up as a clown (in case you were interested). Not sure how she is going to react to facepaint... could all end horribly. Hi to everyone from the DGI thing last night. Looking forward to a continued discussion and the chance to do some good.

Congratulations to Fiona and Stephen who got married on Friday. A great day was had by all (especially my little brother, judging by his hangover). Under the influence of alcohol I was pursuaded to go and see him do his DJ thing in the urlLink Crypt on Sunday night. Sadly the management closed the room due to the small crowd but I managed to get a close look at the scary monster that is Hard House. Good Jaysus.

Handy Tip When preparing for your driving test it's always a good idea to ensure your provisional licence is close at hand. Leaving it in an apartment in Spain can cause mental anguish and result in the uncontrollable laughter of your peers.

Managed to finish 'Dead Air' by Iain Banks last week. Not nearly as good as his earlier stuff, and not even in the same league as his Science Fiction books. It just kind of wanders around looking for a plot... couple of good jokes, nice cover... that's about it. I reckon he just doesn't give a shite anymore... loads of money and all the toys he wants. Shame. Still, its not as bad as 'The Business'.
This is beautiful > urlLink www.simonhoegsberg.com

Car update. Just as I start slagging it off it packs in. Car is now sitting in Dun Laoghaire and won't start according to her indoors. Did I mention my test is on Friday? And it's raining. And I have to cycle home.
urlLink arf arf

Back from our holiday in Spain. A week on the beach digging holes and making sandcastles for the small girl. A great time was had by all. The Euro really makes everything easier to do as you don't have to do all those mental calculations to figure out if you are being ripped off. Spain is really cheap. Can of beer for 60c!! We hired a Ford Galaxy to get around (there was 6 of us plus suitcases, buggies and toys). Brilliant car, A/C, power steering and all those things that people who drive real cars take for granted. Anyone want to buy a '97 Seat Ibiza? On a completely unrelated note, Darren & Gwen have posted their wedding pics urlLink here.

I think I should point out to anyone visiting that I'm not a 'web designer' (if it's not obvious), just a designer who occasionally does stuff for the web. So, my excuse for dodgy code, browser incompatibility and whatever else you think is wrong is the learning curve associated with all this interweb stuff. Plus, I have a life and job to be getting on with. That said I intend to gradually get around to creating something really interesting (for me anyway) that works. Beautiful and Useful in the words of Mr Rand.
When I grow up I want to be like these urlLink these guys.

Direct action and all that. I'll probably end getting the shite beaten out of me by some irate Brennans Bread truck driver. If I end up making these stickers I'll post a PDF somewhere on the site for download. Fight the power (:-))

So I thought it would be cool if you could just click off the layer to reveal the image below. Took Friday off work to go and sort out a new passport. I had to go and get a new birth cert first. Only took about an hour to do that. I was expecting to have to hang around for most of the day so i was a happy bunny. Even found half an hour to drop in to the MSc.Multimedia show in the Douglas Hyde.
Yayyy... I got a urlLink First . Wonder if they'll let me go to the pub?

Oh Shite. I can't find my passport. 9 days to go til me holliers and no sign of the pesky purple fella (!). Spent the (early) morning going through every box and bag in the attic on the off chance, but to no avail. Looks like I may have to go down the route of getting an emergency one from the Passport Office on Molesworth St. That means hassle, stress, 57odd quid in the new money and at least half a day off work. Not to mention the fact that I have no idea where my Birth Cert is. FECK

Good Jaysus, I've just had a look on the PC and the type is all over the place. 100pt Times! Obviously I have no idea what I'm doing. Back to the CSS manual. (And it all looked so simple on paper... sniff)
Well this seems to be working out reasonably well. The type looks OK on my browser. I'll have to go and check it on the PC to make sure. How sad am I!

Revising this site at the moment. Trying to figure out how to use CSS to control the type. It's all over the place at the moment. Ignore the 'old Blog' link. It doesn't work yet. The box on the left will have random images that I've taken recently. Just for fun, so don't read any huge significance into them.

Joe's band (The Connect Four Orchestra) launched their first album in Whelans last Friday... supported by the Redneck Manifesto no less... a great time was had by all.. the lads rocked and I felt very old indeed. You can get the album - 'Chisel to the Hip' in Tower, Freebird and Road. I bought a copy at the gig but managed to leave it in the taxi.. despite the fact that I was stone cold sober. So much for my rock and roll lifestyle. Now, where did I leave me Sting Retrospective... urlLink Check out the fancy schmancy cd cover, interactive CD rom and matching T-Shirt... v.nice. .

Came across a really interesting link on the Coudal Partners site. Its a collection of illustrations done By Tove Jansson for the Hobbit. I really like them - I've been a fan of her books since I was knee high to Moomintroll. It is strange seeing her style in this context though. I suppose its because the subject matter is so familiar and her interpretation is so different. Check out the drawing of Gollum to see what I mean urlLink Here they are .

I've always thought that celebrity walk-ons where a definite sign of urlLink shark jumping and this weeks appearance of Orbital on ER is a case in point. They've run out of jobbing 'used to be famous' TV actors to strip of their dignity (Sally Fields, Alan Alda and erm.. Ewan McGregor) so now they've moved on to the world of music to lend the show some air of edginess. Good Christ - they even had one of the characters moshing off the stage beside the brothers Hartnoll... Dr. Chen I think. So that's the end of ER as far as I'm concerned. Orbital still rock though.

very busy at the moment - everyone wants everything finished before Xmas. At the moment I'm working on a bunch of point of sale for coke and also trying to get a website for CPM into a manageable state. I think its coming together - it's been hard to do and learn flash at the same time so there are several rough edges. I really need a couple of days to just sit down and learn actionscript properly. urlLink here is is The small girl has caught my cold and is feeling pretty miserable at the moment. The good news is that she should be 'all better' for christmas and the arrival of what is looking increasingly like the entire contents of Smyths Toystore.

Busy week ahead. Molly is two this Friday - we are going to have a big picnic in the park on Saturday to celebrate (or in the house if its pelting down). Full list and descriptions of presents next week. Hopefully her pic will be on the Den this Friday - cheers Ruth and Deirdre for that one. Just finished a layout for 'Enlace' which is published by the nice people at the Latin America Solidarity Centre. Took a few liberties with the layout - I think it turned out well but I've got to stop using Beta Sans - its turning into the new Rotis!
dgi t-shirt com is nearly over. this is my entry (although I'm actually disqualified for obvious reason) I like it - don't think anyone else does.

Been very lax in posting to this blog... not that anyone actually reads it mind you, but it is nice to scan over it now and again to see what I was up to this time last year. Molly News Toilet training continues - she is doing really well. Not too many accidents which is unexpected. We had anticipated more mess to be honest.

Back from the second of two stags in as a many weeks - Aiden first and Robbie Bowen last weekend. Solid drinking over the course of a weekend is not good for the soul, liver or pocket. No hangover today but the oul Karma has taken a battering. This is what Aiden and Benny looked like after last weekend - nuff said.

mini review Altered Carbon and Broken Angels by Richard Morgan Overrated by a long shot, hard-boiled cyber noir - extra points for cool tech (stacks and sleeves are good, spooky ancient martian tech - yawn). Let down by the sequel - big build up to not very much... including a twist(s) that I didn't even care about. and. ......why. does. every. character. talk. like. this? Saying that I'd probably still buy a third book (which I'm sure is coming)... but that's because I have no willpower.

Lally, myself and the small girl went to see Duffys Circus last weekend - we had a great time - tigers, clowns, acrobatic kick boxers, dancing ponies and candy floss - and we even got to have our pic taken with a huge snake.

YAYYYY!! Passed my driving test (at last). I was convinced I'd failed, stalled the car on the way out of the test centre and made a f??kin' mess of the reverse, so didn't expect to be handed the cert at the end. Here comes cheaper insurance and best of all - driving cars on holidays... deadly buzz.
Mollyisms # 1 It's not a Fat Frog, it's a stick dressed up as a Fat Frog

After much NCTing, cert filing in and general stuff I finally got my new (and Paulas old) car. It is a 98 Renault Megane Coupe. 1.6 so it has a bit of a kick and it rocks. I've been volunteering to drive everyone everywhere the last week and the novelty still hasn't worn off. The first thing Molly said was 'It's very yellow Daddy', which is true. I'm calling that a built in safety feature. And yellow is making a comeback bigtime. As our Anne said 'very Uma Thurman'. Here it is.
This pic of Molly was floating around on my desktop so I thought I'd post it here. It's from last summer - so she is much taller now.

Books I've bought/borrowed/stolen this year but have yet to finish. Write Right by Jan Venolia. Bought this on the strength of the cover design (by Paul Kepple). It's a guide to Punctuation, Grammar and Style. Nice and informal and easy to dip into.

Myself and Lally had a few days in London last weekend. Stayed urlLink here , had dinner with urlLink Luke and urlLink Deborah , bought loads of stuff and took pictures of urlLink stencils . Also got drunk in urlLink this pub, which was good craic.

Currently testing my willpower by being alcohol free. Don't think I've gone this long without a beer or glass of wine since the early nineties. Wish I could say that my perceptions have sharpened and that I've found a new way of looking at the world but it wouldn't be true. Jaysus I'm dying for a pint.
Anne and Tony got engaged! And we destroyed Mary Bowens garden building a deck and patio. Can I sleep now? urlLink pics here

When you 'see' something, you do so only after the light reflected from that object has passed through the interventing air and dust and other particles, the cornea, the lens, the aqueous humour, and struck the retina, where the photons have activated G-protein coupled receptors, which in turn have disasscoiated from their tri-partate state, beginnning a signal cascade which potentiates membranes which cause electrical currents to flow along nerves to synapses where neurotransmitters of various flavours are released by one neuron and absorbed by another, again causing a change in membrane potential. This goes on for some time, until the inputs from the various retinal cells along various neurons are re-assembled by other neurons in the visual cortex of the brain and the message is transmitted to the frontal cortex of the brain, where-upon you 'see' the object. Walter R. Strapps, Ph.D. part of a thread on soc.history.what-if
This is getting ridiculous. I think we have to draw up a dress code or something.

We moved house on the 12th. it was all surprisingly easy. Stress free in fact, until we got to the new house. Removal company arrived at 9.30 and were out in about 3 hours. Its a bit depressing to see all your worldly goods packed into a van and not even fill it. Signed contracts at 2.30 and were in the new house around 3. Having spent the last week scrubbing and cleaning the old house within an inch of its life we were disappointed to find that the new house last received a wash sometime in the mid-sixties. It was manky. Very strong smell of fags and nearly every surface was coated in grease. So it was back to the scrubbing and scraping again. Lots of work to do but everything seems to be going to plan. Main bedroom is painted and we should have a couple more rooms done by the end of the week. Floors are being sanded tomorrow and the kitchen starts to go in on Friday. urlLink Here are some random pics. More soon.

urlLink latest issue of enlace. Did this a few weeks ago in about 3 hours (that's my excuse anyway). Not as succesful as the first one. I had hoped to use Ziggurat for the heads and spend some more time developing the look around it... but sadly this is a zero budget project so it didn't happen.
